questions.question:
Question 1: Which of the following is the ultimate long-term desired state towards which all the resources 
are directed?
questions.explanation:
The goal is the ultimate desired state towards which objectives and resources are directed. It is 
long-term and not constrained by time or resources. The plan is the blueprint for taking action in order to achieve the goal. Option A: Target refers to the quantifiable and achievable mid-term endpoints in the plan. Option B: Mission describes the cause of the existence of the programme. Option D: The objectives are short-term endpoints. They are precise points in the plan. They are 
either achieved or unachieved.

questions.question:
Question 2: Which of the following is a set of rules that helps ensure maximum use of the resources and 
efforts?
questions.explanation:
Procedure is a set of rules for carrying out work. It helps to ensure the maximum use of resources 
and efforts. Option B: Programme is a sequence of activities designed to implement policies and accomplish 
objectives. Option C: Schedule is a time sequence for the work to be done. Option D: Target refers to the quantifiable and achievable mid-term endpoints in the plan.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following is not a component of the evaluation of health programs?
questions.explanation:
Repeatability is not a component of the evaluation of health programs. Components of evaluation are: (Mnemonic: Ryan Always Ate An Egg Every Evening) • Relevance • Adequacy • Accessibility • Acceptability • Effectiveness • Efficiency • Effect or impact The steps of evaluation of a health programme are: • Determine what is to be evaluated: structure, process, or outcome • Establish standards and criteria • Plan the methodology to be applied 733 
Sold by @itachibot • Gather information • Analyze the results • Take action • Re-evaluate

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following techniques is based on behavioral sciences?
questions.explanation:
Management by objective is based on behavioral sciences. Management methods used in health programmes are either quantitative or based on behavioral 
sciences. Methods based on behavioral sciences include: • Organizational design • Personnel management • Communication • Information systems • Management by objectives (MBO) Quantitative methods include: • Cost-benefit analysis • Cost-effective analysis • Cost–accounting • Input-output analysis • Model • Systems analysis • Network analysis - includes programme evaluation and review technique (PERT) and critical 
path method (CPM) • Planning–programming–budgeting system (PPBS) • Work sampling • Decision making

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is a quantitative method of management?
questions.explanation:
Cost-benefit analysis is a quantitative method of management. In this method, the economic benefits of any programme are compared with the costs 
incurred. The benefit of the programme is expressed in monetary units. The main drawback here 
is that the benefits of a health programme cannot always be expressed in monetary terms. 734

questions.question: Question 8: What is the programme evaluation and review technique used for?
questions.explanation:
The programme evaluation and review technique (PERT) is used for network analysis. It is a type of quantitative management technique which helps in detailed planning and 
comprehensive supervision.

questions.question:
Question 12: Which committee had recommended a bachelor degree in medical education for rural health 
services?

options.b: High-level expert group on universal health coverage
options.d: Committee on Integration of Health Services

questions.explanation:
The high-level expert group (HLEG) on universal health coverage under the aegis of the Planning 
Commission of India suggested a 3.5 year bachelor degree course in medical education for rural 
health services. This was planned for the 12th five-year plan (2012-2017). The degree given was B.Sc Community 
Health, and these rural health care practitioners were to be called community health officers.

questions.question:
Question 13: Who was appointed as the chairman of the Health Survey and Development Committee in 
1943?
questions.explanation:
Sir Joseph William Bhore was appointed as the chairman of the Health Survey and Development 
Committee in 1943. This committee was hence named the Bhore committee. 737 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 14: Which health planning committee proposed the 3 million plan?
questions.explanation: The 3 million plan was proposed by the Bhore Committee. It proposed to set up the following in the long-term: • Primary health units with 75-bedded hospitals for each 10,000 to 20,000 population • Secondary units with 650 beds • District hospitals with 2,500 beds As a short-term measure, it was proposed that each PHC must cater to 40,000 people and have: • 2 medical officers, 4 public health nurses, 1 nurse • 4 midwives, 4 dais, 2 sanitary inspectors, 2 health assistants • 1 pharmacist • 15 other class IV employees

questions.question:
Question 15: What is the provision of preventive, curative, and promotional health services to every 
individual called?
questions.explanation:
Comprehensive health care as stated by the Bhore committee means giving integrated preventive, 
curative, and promotional health care to every individual, irrespective of their ability to pay.

questions.question:
Question 16: In the inventory management of drug stores, which of the following is a component of the 
VED method?
questions.explanation:
The 'D' in the VED method stands for desirable. VED is a method of inventory management used mainly in drug stores and pharmacies. 738 
Sold by @itachibot The drugs are classified in three categories as follows: • V - Vital drugs. Items whose absence cannot be tolerated (10% of total items). • E - Essential drugs. Items whose absence can be tolerated for some time (40% of total items). • D - Desirable drugs. Items whose absence can be tolerated for a long time (50% of total items).

What is this method known as?

The method of analysis depicted above is the ABC analysis (always better control). It refers to 
a type of inventory management in which items are divided into 3 categories according to their 
cost. This type of analysis aims to calculate expenditures of large proportions on a small number of 
items and vice versa. It makes it easier to understand how to control the majority of expenditure 
by analyzing the small numbers of items it is being spent on. questions.question: Question 19: Which article of the Indian Constitution confers Right to Life to the citizens of India?
questions.explanation:
The Right to Life is given in Article 21 of the Indian Constitution. Option A: Article 11 defines the right of the parliament to regulate the right of citizenship by law. Option C: Article 23 defines the prohibition of traffic in human beings and forced labor. Option D: Article 25 defines the freedom of conscience and free profession, practice, and 
propagation of religion. 740 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following is part of the concurrent list of the Indian Constitution?

options.a: Few of their responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers
options.b: They should have formal education at least up to class 10
options.c: A population of 1000 should have at least 1 ASHA

questions.explanation:
Adulteration of food is included under the concurrent list. The legislative section of the seventh schedule is divided into three lists: • Union list - a list of 100 items on which the parliament has exclusive power to legislate • State list - a list of 61 items on which the state government has exclusive power to legislate • Concurrent list - a list of 52 items on which both central and state governments have the power 
to legislate 741
